Let’s talk about travel companions. 

While travelling around the world I’ve seen people traveling with human and non human travel companions. In non-humans, dogs 🐕 and cats 🐈 are usually the winner. But on my last trip to #thailand I saw a girl traveling with a different kind of a companion. I was so mesmerized by this little thing that I forgot I was there to visit one of the most revered and famous ancient temples of #lampang - Wat Phrathat Lampang Luang.

Btw I highly recommend you to visit Lampang if you are visiting Thailand. Quite untouristy and interesting to explore. 

Have you come across people travelling with unique companions?

#travelseewrite #unexploredplaces #amazingthailand #tbexasia2022 #trendingreels #trendingsongs #trendingnow #petsofinstagram #pets #templesofthailand #norththailand #chiangmai

3 must visit places in #chiangmaithailand - 

1) Royal Rose Garden Restaurant in Huai Phak Phai Royal Project - I was super happy to visit this #sustainablefarming site. The 474 acres project was established in 1980 on a degraded forest area with a mission to improve the living quality of local villagers. There are 3 villages that the project is looking after, in total 321 families or 1,766 people. The food served here was mindblowing and completely from #farmtotable.

2) Wat Phra Singh temple - known as “The monastery of the Lion Buddha” this temple is considered as the most attractive temple in Chiang Mai. 

3) Wat Chedi Luang- this 14th century Temple, where the City Pillar Shrine is located, is famous for its enormous chedi, which is measured at 282 feet high and 144 feet wide (at the base).

Have you been to #chiangmai? If not, start planning now.

📸 thanks @therovingheart & @exoticgringo for being so patiently shooting me 😃🤩

#travelseewrite #amazingthailand #tbex2022 #northernthailand #trendingreels #trendingsongs #offbeattravel #sustainabletravel #lonelyplanetindia #outlooktraveller

Often referred to as the land of dawn-lit mountains, #Arunachal Pradesh is the first Indian soil to greet the rising sun. Despite being home to picturesque mountains, unexplored passes, tranquil lakes and famous monasteries, the state still happens to be one of the least explored regions in India. Along with the natural attractions, the North Eastern State is a perfect state to explore the tribal culture and the simplicity of their daily lives.

I recently visited the state to attend a 4-day long #womenbikingexpedition and #orangefestival. Here’s a small glimpse from one of the many hidden gems of the state - #Pasighat - the land of the mighty #Siang and indigenous hanging bridges. 

If you haven’t been to the state yet, perhaps it’s the right time to plan one.

PS: This post is part of my latest series - #TravelSeeWriteInNorthEast. Stay tuned for more updates.

#letsexplorebeyond #visitarunachal #explorebeyond_ap @arunachaltsm @explorebeyond.exp @watworxlive

Must-try experience in #arunachalpradesh - white water river rafting in the mighty #dibangriver that originates from Indo - Tibetan border. It’s a river where very few explorations are done. There are only a couple of rafting expeditions done on the river. It is a raging, wild, fast, remote and unexplored part of Arunachal that will leave you spellbound with its beauty. 

We drove for 1.5 hr off road from our Resort in #bomjir to reach the #dibangriver confluence point through rocky riverbed, grassland and water puddles.

There were rapids from Grade I to IV. Usually it’s a full day activity but we could only do it for 2hrs. However, those 2hrs became the most memorable part of my #arunchaltrip .

If you haven’t been here, you must plan soon.

📸 @dewan.vikram 

PS: this post is part of my #travelseewriteinnortheast series.

#explorebeyond #arunchalpradeshtourism #letsexplorebeyond #visitarunachal #travelseewrite @arunachaltsm @explorebeyond.exp @watworxlive

One word that can sum up New Year’s Eve in Las Vegas : Crazy. And I mean crazy in a good way. The entire #vegasstrip is shut down to traffic and it becomes like one giant block party for over 300,000 of people. At midnight, the casinos launch a choreographed fireworks display that makes the Times Square ball drop look like child’s play. 

Inside, Las Vegas shows rock with the hottest entertainment and nightclubs in Las Vegas are packed with celebrities and partygoers who are dressed to impress. This year there was Bruno Mars, Chris Brown, Adele, and whose who of the world.

I was overjoyed to ring in the new year in the Entertainment Capital of the World.

Where did you celebrate New Year’s Eve?

“If you truly love nature, you will find beauty everywhere.” — Vincent Van Gogh

Couldn’t agree more. So whether it’s a city or a national park, dam or river, local culture or giant woods, I find beauty in everything I see. 

It was second visit to #hooverdam and I enjoyed it equally or maybe a little more. #travelseewrite #travelseewriteinusa 

Hoover Dam is a concrete arch-gravity dam in the Black Canyon of the Colorado River, on the border between the U.S. states of Nevada and Arizona. It was constructed between 1931 and 1936 during the Great Depression and was dedicated on September 30, 1935, by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

When Hoover Dam was built, the canyons began to fill water from the Colorado River, creating Lake Mead. This depth, coupled with very clear water, sunny skies and lots of dissolved minerals, gives the lake its signature blue color.

Have you been here?

Is #SantaCruz worth visiting?

With 29 miles of sun-drenched coastline, Santa Cruz County offers some of California’s best beaches, 
 spectacular oceanfront walks, and expansive beaches, but I was equally interested in exploring the hiking and biking trails here (especially the #redwoods) and enjoy the topnotch dining options and wine tasting.

Unfortunately, the weather played the spoilsport. And, might not be able to enjoy Santa Cruz in its full glory. Nonetheless today was a good day. Here’s a glimpse for you…

Have you been to Santa Cruz yet?

#visitcalifornia #visitsantacruz #westcliff #santacruzwestcliff #monterey #visitusa

They say no storm lasts forever. After the storm the sun will shine again. 

No truer words could have been said than what I witnessed today. After a completely washed out day today I got a small window of hardly 5 minutes to witness this glorious sunset at one of the most stunning beach and surfing destinations not just in #california but probably in the whole of the USA.

And, as luck would have it I was at the right place at the right time when this beautiful surfer came out of the waves and the sun was setting right behind her.  Talk about timing! Huh!!!

I am in love with this shot. This shot defines everything that #santacruz in California stands for. 

I couldn’t have been more thankful to God for the life I have and the people I meet. Despite a bad start of the day I had an amazing day overall.

I hope this shot inspires you to check out this place and look beyond what looks really depressing. There’s always light after the dark tunnel. Keep looking.

In #SantaCruz County, the fun only begins at the beach. Here is why I fell in love with the place despite a ravaging storm.

1)	LOCATION & ACTIVITIES - A short drive from both #SanJose and #SanFrancisco, Santa Cruz makes for the perfect weekend getaway and is famous for great surfing beaches, redwood-covered mountains, laid-back towns,  organic farms, and a burgeoning beer and wine scene.
2)	SANTA CRUZ WHARF - Built in 1914 as the longest timber-pile wharf in the United States, the wharf is a means of commerce and recreation for the community and visitors.
3)	DREAM INN & JACK O-NEILL RESTAURANT- A Santa Cruz favourite for surfing, sunsets and California cuisine, Dream Inn is a beloved local landmark for staying and eating.
4)	NATURAL BRIDGES STATE PARK AND BEACH - an ideal place for tidepool exploration and butterfly watching.
5)	SCENIC WEST CLIFF DRIVE - Between Natural Bridges State Beach and the Santa Cruz Municipal Wharf, a 2.5-mile scenic path was truly stunning. 
6)	SHADOWBROOK RESTAURANT – known for “romance in dining” since 1947, this place has got everything right – food, drinks, ambience and fantastic service.
7)	Wine tasting – A trip to Santa Cruz is incomplete without wine tasting. While there are many tasting rooms,  I loved @birichino_official for making unusually delicious wines that give pleasure, revitalize, and revive. 
8)	THE PENNY ICE CREAMERY - small-batch local, seasonal and organic ice creams made in-house completely from scratch.
9)	GAYLE’S BAKERY + ROSTICCERIA - a Capitola landmark and THE place to be for locals.  Handmade pastries, salads, sandwiches and coffee drinks.
10)	BOOKSHOP SANTA CRUZ – big brands have come and gone,  but this legendary independent bookstore has not only survived but thrived since 1966.

I hope these photos inspire you to check out Santa Cruz on your next visit to Northern California.

Follow the sun wherever it leads.

When I followed the sun in #SantaCruz, it led me to a beautiful place called Pleasure Point. This charming beach community area enlivens Hollywood movies and lures envious tourists to California’s sunny shores year-round. Situated on Santa Cruz’s east end, this seaside neighborhood is one of the most vibrant surf destinations along the California coast. The easy-going neighborhood earned its hedonistic name from Prohibition-era shenanigans, but you’d swear it’s because spending a day here is such a joy, no surfboard required.

Are you intrigued to check this place out?

There’s something about penguins that make them so adorable. Also, because penguins are so beloved, they are uniquely capable of teaching us about love for the natural world. And, that’s what @montereybayaquarium is also trying to teach us.

Frolicking sea otters, fast-swimming sharks, pulsating jellies and waddling penguins are some world-class exhibits I saw at @montereybayaquarium. With over 200 exhibits and 80,000 plants and animals, the Aquarium is a window to the ocean's wonders.

Since its opening in 1984, Monterey Bay Aquarium’s mission has been to inspire the conservation of the oceans. The Aquarium’s collective efforts have helped Monterey County become the third certified “Green Destination” in the United States on the Global Destination Sustainability Index.

At the Aquarium, I learnt how they are trying to tackle ocean plastic pollution through research, education, business initiatives and science-based policies.

If you are in the region, I highly recommend you check out this place.

Have you heard about Paso Robles?

If you love great wine, thrilling activities without the crowds, innovative dining and open roads, then you’ll #PasoRobles. Paso Robles Wine Country is a very distinct area with more than 200 tasting rooms and 40,000 vineyard acres producing more than 40 wine grape varieties. Here are the three must-do things in #PasoRobles

1)	Try wine-tasting with immaculate food pairing at @roberthallwinery, one of the world’s top regenerative organic wineries.
2)	Besides wine, Paso Robles is famous for its olives. And the best place to try different varieties of olive oil and seasoning is @pasolivo which has won numerous awards for its estate-grown olive oil. 
3)	Stay at  Lofts at @pasomarketwalk – a unique space for artisanal eats and two full Michelin-recommended restaurants.

Have you been to #PasoRobles?

#TravelPaso @travelpaso #visitcalifornia #visitusa #travelseewrite #travelseewriteinusa  #travelblogger #visitusa #visitcaliforniapartner #trendingsongs

How far will you travel for a glass of wine🍷?

I travelled 12,615km from New Delhi, India to Paso Robles in California to try out one of the finest wines in the world from @roberthallwinery, which is not only a fantastic winery but is one of the world’s top regenerative organic wineries. 

I had a great experience trying out their delicious and elaborate four course wine-paired lunch. 

It was one of the highlights of my #centralcoastcalifornia road trip experience.

If you ever #visitcalifornia I’d highly recommend going to this highly offbeat place that produces great wines.

#travelpaso #roberthall #roberthallwinery #pasolivo #pasorobleswinecountry #pasorobles #pasoroblescalifornia #pasoroblesdowntown #trending #trendingreels #trendingnow #travelseewrite #travelseewriteinusa #visitcaliforniapartner #californiacoast

@travelandleisure named Paso Robles one of the Best Small Towns to Retire in the U.S. After visiting it recently, I know why it got that honour.

Located halfway between San Francisco and Los Angeles, Paso Robles is a city of around 31,000 residents. A walkable downtown features restaurants ranging from casual coffee shops to upscale dining, shops, galleries, breweries, wine-tasting rooms, and entertainment. Nearby, wineries are set among picturesque rolling hills, many with outdoor areas for picnics. Summers are warm, and the coast is just a half hour away with several beaches and seaside towns.

Why wouldn’t anyone wanna retire here? I would definitely.

Would you?

I am addicted to #oxnard and can’t get enough of it.

Located only sixty miles northwest of #losangeles and in close proximity to #santabarbara and other major destinations, Oxnard is one of California’s best kept secrets.

Visit this quaint little place to enjoy pristine golden duned beaches, whale watching, electric nightlife, some of the best taquerias in the state, historic Victorian era architecture, the California Strawberry Festival, and an expansively picturesque harbor that serves as the closest access point to the Channel Islands National Park.

While it’s mostly famous for outdoors, I loved its indoor attractions too. 

And, don’t forget to visit small wine tasting rooms like @streycellars for an authentic #venturacounty hospitality.

Hello from Kazakhstan!

It’s my first time in Kazakhstan and I can’t tell you how impressed I am with its natural beauty and people.

Do you know Kazakhstan is the ninth largest country in the world, covering an area equivalent to Western Europe, and the largest landlocked country. 

Kazakhstan is one of the most ethnically and religiously diverse nations, owing to not only its history and nomadic culture, but also its geography, situated in between the major world religions. 

This view is from one of the most popular ski resorts of Kazakhstan #shimbulak near #almaty 

Almaty, the former capital, is revered as the country’s most beautiful city. A cultural melting pot of 131 ethnicities, home to stunning nature, including the famed Altai mountains and Kazakh steppe, as well as the Golden Man, the country’s Tutankhamun, Kazakhstan offers the ultimate adventure.

If you haven’t been to #kazakhstan, this is the right time to plan.

#kazakh #almatytoday #shimbulakskiresort #centralasia #travelseewrite #travelblogger #offbeattravel #winterwonderland #trendingreels

Winter in #Kyrgyzstan is magical - everything is covered with white snow. And, the best way to explore the winter beauty of this offbeat destination is by doing horse riding. 

Horses are like a oxygen to the nomads of #kyrgyzstan whose entire life depends on them be it transportation, hunting, food, entertainment or even keeping themselves warm in winters. 

Yesterday, I first attended the ancient horse games of the local nomads of Kyrgyzstan followed by horse riding in a snowfall. 

It was truly a memorable day.

Have you ever been to Kyrgyzstan? If not, plan your tour now.

#kyrgyzstan - Snow glad to see you!

Day 3 of our #kyrgyzsnowdrive

We drove from #Kemin to #Naryn covering 211 KMS. It was one of the most thrilling off-road drive we did so far in this trip where we passed through untouched virgin valleys, deep gorges, sky piercing mountains and snow covered pastures that were once green pastures! Unlike the day before the sun gave us a good company. The last leg of our journey was something I can’t express in words. You have to see it to believe it. 

Here’s a small glimpse of what we saw yesterday.

Have you been to #kyrgyzstan ? If not, plan to visit today.

#snowwhite #kyrgyzstan🇰🇬 #offbeattravel #wintertravel #wintertrip #roadtrip #travelseewrite #trendingreels #trending

Snow excited to be in #kyrgyzstan . 

On Day 4 of my #kyrgyzsnowdrive we drove from #Naryn to #kochkor Via #sonkul lake coveting 265 kms. Lying at an altitude of 3016 m, the route to #sonkullake was fully frozen and I felt like I was walking in a winter wonderland. The temperature res he’d as low as -12 Celsius. Thankfully it was bright and sunny. One of the most memorable day of this trip.

Here’s a small trailer for you. 

If you haven’t been here, you must plan a trip to #kyrgyzstan

Kyrgyzstan has traditionally always been a summer destination for adventure-seeking travellers. This landlocked mountainous country is undoubtedly beautiful at any time of year, but it becomes especially magical when covered in a fresh layer of snow. I am so glad I could see it’s #narnia like beauty in winters. 

From postcard-worthy alpine lakes such as #songkul to the red rock rainbows in Skazka Canyon, you could stay here for a month or more exploring some of the most stunning vistas on earth.

But if you are tight on time a 7-day #kyrgyzsnowdrive is a perfect way to get a glimpse of what this stunning country has to offer. 

Here’s a small sneak for you.

When someone asks where is HOME?

I take a moment to answer. 

Is it the place where I was born or where I studied or where I started my career or something else?

Home, for me, is really a WIP (Work In Progress).

It’s like a project on which I constantly add upgrades, improvements and corrections.

For me, home is less to do with a piece of soil than with a peace of SOUL.

Why visit #Kyrgyzstan in winter?

Once a part of the USSR, #Kyrgystan is a 96% mountainous country. While most people visit it during summer when it’s ideal for hikes and the roads are in better condition. But I thoroughly enjoyed visiting in winter. Here are my reasons for visiting it in winter:

1)	SNOWSCAPES: If you live in a country like India, then seeing snow-covered landscapes is a major draw. And Kyrgyzstan is covered with a thick blanket of snow in winter and it feels like you are in Narnia
2)	LESS BUSY – Winter is not the peak season, which means fewer tourists and more budget-friendly (although Kyrgyzstan is overall a very economical destination)
3)	 IMMERSIVE CULTURAL ACTIVITIES – In winter you can spend more time immersing yourself in cultural activities such as spending time with yurt-dwelling shepherds who come down in winter, Eagle Hunters, Kyrgyz Musicians, Carpet Weavers, Horse riders etc
4)	ALPINE LAKES – The high altitude lakes of Kyrgyzstan #Sonkul, #IssykKul look otherworldly in winters
5)	SNOW DRIVE - An adrenaline activity that tests your extreme weather driving skills.
6)	SKIING – While I don’t ski, Kyrgyzstan is a great place to Ski.

Do swipe left to get a glimpse of winter time in #KyrgyzRepublic.

Be like a waterfall, wild and free!

Life doesn’t flow backwards and so shouldn’t you. But sometimes it’s good to refresh memories, revisit the same place and create new memories.

That’s what I did when I visited @lakeplitvice again this year after a gap of 5 years and in a different season. 

#PlitviceLakesNational Park is a natural wonderland located in #Croatia, and it is one of the most popular tourist destinations in the country. The park is known for its stunning natural beauty, with cascading waterfalls, crystal-clear lakes, and lush green forests. While the park is undoubtedly a must-visit during the summer, it's worth noting that each season brings its own unique charm to the area. I happen to visit it in two seasons – start of Spring & Summers.

In the spring, Plitvice Lakes National Park comes alive with vibrant colours and blossoming flowers. This season is a great time to visit if you want to avoid the crowds of the peak summer season. You can witness the park's waterfalls flowing at their maximum capacity, which creates a stunning spectacle. Additionally, the surrounding forests are at their most lush during spring, and you can spot various bird species that come to the park during this time of the year.

However, Summer is the peak season at Plitvice Lakes National Park, and it's easy to see why. The sun shines brightly, and the park's lakes and waterfalls are at their most impressive. Visitors can take a leisurely stroll on the wooden walkways that snake around the park's 16 lakes, or they can take a boat ride to experience the area's natural beauty up close.

Here’s a mini travel guide of visiting one of Europe’s most stunning and Instagram-worthy destinations? 

#PlitviceLakesNationalPark is a #UNESCOWorldHeritageSite that boasts 16 cascading waterfalls, crystal-clear lakes, and lush forests that will take your breath away.

Here’s what you need to know before you go.

To visit the park, you can enter through one of its four entrances. The park is open year-round, but it’s best to visit between April to October, when the weather is mild and the foliage is at its peak.

To enter the park, there’s an entrance fee that varies depending on the time of year and the entrance you choose. Prices range from 7 euros to 34 euros per person.

The park is divided into 2 main sections: the Upper Lakes and the Lower Lakes. The Upper Lakes are known for their clear blue-green waters and the Lower Lakes for their dramatic waterfalls. You can also take a boat ride or guided tour to learn more about the park’s flora and fauna.

Once inside the park, you can choose from several different routes, ranging in difficulty and length. The shortest route takes about 2-3 hours to complete, while the longest takes 6-8 hours..

So how much time do you need to explore @lakeplitvice? That depends on the route you choose and how much time you want to spend taking in the park’s natural beauty. But plan for at least a half-day visit to fully appreciate everything the park has to offer.

So grab your camera and get ready to experience the enchanting beauty of Plitvice Lakes for yourself!”

Revisiting the birthplace of the greatest inventor of all times: 

Nikola Tesla Memorial Centre

I was pleasantly surprised when I first visited this place. After all one of the greatest minds of the modern world came from the tiny village of #Smiljan, 5km west of #Gospić in #Croatia. #NikolaTesla – the man responsible for bringing electricity into our homes and inventing wireless technology – was born here. This fascinating museum includes displays about his life and working replicas of some of his most famous inventions.

The original memorial site built in 1956 was damaged during the Yugoslavia War. Tesla's father was a Serbian Orthodox priest and, sadly, the family house, barn and church on this site were torched during the 1990s war. 

What stands here today is a reconstruction, financed by the Croatian government.

Still this is a place, I would highly recommend you to visit.

Special thanks to @maja.strilic & @boris_lu810 for organising this visit.

If there is one village that best embodies Austria, and whose picture is on display in every souvenir shop in Austria, it’s #Hallstatt.

Hallstatt, a #UNESCOWorldHeritageSite, is considered to be one of the most beautiful and oldest inhabited settlements in entire Europe. When I visited Hallstatt, I  realized why. This Upper Austrian town, nestled on the shores of Lake Hallstatt, sits beside snow-capped mountains and forests, and the houses have delightful Alpine architecture painted in bright yellows and reds.

Must-do things in Hallstatt are:

1)	Take the Salzwelten funicular railway to the World Heritage Skywalk 
2)	Explore the Hallstatt Charnel Bone House
3)	Visit one of the world’s oldest salt mines 
4)	Explore the town on foot
5)	Tour Lake Hallstatt by boat
6)	Capture the beauty of the village’s very own waterfall
7)	Feast on local Austrian cuisine, beer & homemade pastries

Unfortunately, during summer, Hallstatt suffers from over-tourism, with 10,000 to 30,000 visitors daily in a tiny town of 800 inhabitants. The situation became so bad that the local administration decided to limit the number of incoming tourist buses to 54 a day, with priority given to organised groups with hotels booked for the night.

Therefore as a #ResponsibleTraveller, I’d request you to #VisitHallstatt in shoulder seasons like spring or early autumn. You’ll enjoy this incredible place to the fullest as I did. And, do stay here at least for a night.

PS: Now it’s super easy to visit Hallstatt as @airindia.in has launched direct flight from Delhi to Vienna. Book your flight today.

Are you tired of visiting cities with the same old fountains and plazas? 

Let me introduce you to a hidden gem in central #Bosnia 🇧🇦 that will give you something new to explore. 

Presenting 📍 JAJCE.

Imagine a stunning 22-meter-high waterfall right in the centre of the town; that’s the #JajceWaterfall. It’s not just beautiful but also recognized as one of the 12 most beautiful waterfalls in the world.

But wait, there’s more! Jajce is also home to the Great and Small #PlivaLakes, and #PlivaWatermills, making it a natural paradise. For history buffs, Jajce was the capital of the independent Kingdom of Bosnia, and there’s so much to explore, like the remains of the #JajceFortress, and #JajceCatacombs, an underground church built during the Ottoman period.

But what touched me most about Jajce was the people and their hospitality. So pack your bags and plan a trip to this offbeat destination today. #Jajce is waiting for you!

Do you know which was the first city in the world to receive public lighting?

No, it’s not London, Paris or New York, but the streets of Šibenik, a tiny medieval town in Croatia, were lit up in 1895.

Not just that, Šibenik is also the oldest Croatian city on the #DalmatianCoast, established in the middle ages. It is less touristy but equally charming when compared with its more popular neighbouring cousins such as #Zadar, #Split and #Dubrovnik.

Established in the 11th century, Šibenik is known as the gateway to the Kornati islands. Guarded by five fortresses, the pocket-sized town has an amazing coastal vibe and is very famous among music and history lovers. The beautifully preserved old town gives you the vibe of the 15th and 16th-century era. And perhaps, that’s why it even featured in Game of Thrones Season 5.

This walkable city has a lot to see, such as the St. James Cathedral, St. Michael’s Fortress, St. Nicholas Fortress, St. John’s Fortress, Aquapark and a lot more. 

Most importantly, this is the only county to have two national parks – #Krka & #Kornati.

So, when are you visiting Šibenik?

social_posts.post_text:
Are you a tea lover?

Then you should absolutely visit Sri Lanka Tea Gardens to try out one of the world’s most premium tea that is now synonymous with the name Ceylon. Praised for its unique taste and signature aroma, Sri Lanka is currently the fourth largest tea producer in the world and one of the world’s leading tea exporters.

Tea in Sri Lanka originated over two hundred years ago, when the country was still under British rule. The tea plantation industry in Sri Lanka (formerly known as Ceylon) began in 1825, after the widespread growth of coffee in the early 1800s.

I got an opportunity to witness the entire tea producing journey from tea garden to cup at @bluefieldteasrilanka.

Have you visited Sri Lanka yet? If not, plan your trip now.

Why Visit Yala National Park?

Simply because it is one of the oldest and richest national parks in Sri Lanka, where you can still find wild elephants in the wild.

Moreover, you can spot 215 species of birds and 44 species of mammals here. 

I myself saw dozens of water buffaloes, spotted deer, sambar deer, mongoose, rabbit, crocodile, kingfisher, white kingfisher, langur, wild boar, jackals, wild cat, peacocks, and wild peafowl (the national bird of Sri Lanka) among other animals and birds.

It is said that Yala National Park has the highest density of leopards in the world. Unfortunately, the shy cats were too shy to give us DARSHAN despite our drive-cum-guide Sudarshan trying his best to make us see them.

Lastly, our super Guide, Theeksana, told us that the park is very rich in different ecosystems. Apparently, there are 8 types of ecosystems - moist monsoon forests, dry monsoon forests, semi deciduous forests, thorn forests, grasslands, marshes, marine wetlands, and sandy beaches.

So, have I convinced you to visit #YalaNationalPark? If not, wait for my detailed blog and vlog on the same.

POV: Rain or Shine, I’m Feeling Fine

This isn’t just a statement but a state of mind that I’ve been trying to live by for many years now.

Honestly, it’s not easy to live alone on your terms or be 100% yourself, especially when the society is designed to follow a herd mentality. Where a girl’s ASTITVA gets completed only when she becomes someone’s wife, or mother. We speak about equality and women empowerment, but let me burst your myth. If you are single and not on the right side of 30s, you’ll be looked upon as someone who is either AVAILABLE (for any tom tick and harry), or has some deep issue. Right from a plumber to a jet-setter client will try to take an advantage of you. Age, caste, creed, education, social status no bar. The hand that you’ll feed will come back to bite you. People will not treat you like a professional but someone who can be easily cheated on. 

Not sure how many of you have faced this but I can’t even remember the count now. The only thing that has kept me sane is my WILL to NEVER GIVE UP. Be it RAIN or SHINE, I always try to be FINE. 

But I’ll be honest there are times when I feel bogged down with situations beyond my control. In those moments, I turn to my friends who have always stood by me like a rock.

Have you faced this in your life? Do share your comments.

#singleinthecity #solotraveller #SoloGirl #singlebutnotavailable #singlegirls #singlewomen #singlelifeproblems

📍Ravana Falls, Srilanka 

According to legend, it is said that King Ravana kidnapped Princess Sita and held her captive in a cave, and the #RavanaFalls nearby were where she used to bathe. Therefore, this waterfall carries a huge mythological significance due to its history.

Although the story of this waterfall has always been retold in different versions. One of them seemed more interesting & slightly more unbelievable than the rest that was narrated by my extremely knowledgeable and likeable guide, @_theeka_. He said that it is believed Ravana didn’t die in the Epic war with Rama but hid behind this waterfall. He is in a deep state of concentration and will eventually come out of it when the time is right.

What do you think? Which version do you prefer? Do share your feedback in the comments section.

Ravana Falls, located just 10 minutes away from #Ella by bus, is a must-visit destination for anyone exploring the region. With water cascading down from a height of over 80 feet in a lush green area, it is a picture-perfect spot for nature lovers and photographers.

Have you ever stayed at a Tea Factory?

I did when I stayed at @heritanceteafactory in #NuwaraEliya in #SriLanka

As you enter this 200 year old tea factory, you get an impression as if time has frozen and you have returned to 19th century Ceylon. Much of the original Tea Factory machinery and ambience has been restored to give you an authentic tea factory experience right from plucking the tea leaves to a hot cuppa of Ceylon tea. At one point of time it was the highest tea factory in the world. 

Things that stood out for me here:

1)	Location - surrounded by misty mountains and acres of lush tea estates.
2)	Authentic Tea-factory welcome and tea factory inspired hotel décor
3)	TCK 6685 (Railway Carriage) Restaurant which is a full-size replica of the actual train’s restaurant, sitting on its small-gauge rails
4)	Sustainable Practices – starting from their water management system to waste reduction; organic farming and more importantly providing local employment.
5)	Tea Experiences - there is a miniature but working tea factory located outside of the hotel where you can learn about how world famous Ceylon Tea is made. Also, they have tea tastings organised for visitors
6)	Staff – very warm and welcoming.

Let me introduce you to the hidden secret of Balkans - #zabljak . 

Žabljak Montenegro – Meet the highest town in the Balkans.

Did you know that in the northern part of Montenegro, there is a beautiful, fairytale-like town known for its untouched and miraculous nature? Exactly 1,456 meters above sea level in the heart of Mount Durmitor, you can find Zabljak – one of the most breathtaking places I visited during my last visit to the Balkans.

Zabljak Municipality is the most inhabited town in the Balkan peninsula, with only 1,700 people. As a part of National Park Durmitor, it is one of the most visited places in Southern Europe.

Since #ZabljakMontenegro is situated in the heart of the Durmitor mountain, this is a true paradise for the adventure seekers like me.

My top 5 activities to do in #Žabljak are: 
1.	Spend some time in the Durmitor National Park hiking, biking, river rafting or other adventure activities.
2.	Visit the deepest gorge in Europe – Tara River Gorge
3.	Spend some time at the Black Lake
4.	Become friends with the locals of Crna Gora (Little Montenegro) village
5.	Go on a Durmitoring Jeep Tour with @soaexperience 

Don’t forget to swipe left and check all the pics. 

So, when are you visiting Žabljak?

🌍✈️ Wanderlust on a budget! 

Still wondering where to go on a holiday that is both cheap and no visa drama? 

Here are 5 incredible countries where Indians can travel hassle-free and visa-free, offering amazing experiences:

1️) Azerbaijan: Unveil the land of fire with its rich heritage and modern marvels. Explore the UNESCO-listed Old City of Baku and immerse yourself in the stunning landscapes of the Caucasus. e-visa for last minute program!

2️) Kyrgyzstan: Discover the hidden gems of Central Asia in Kyrgyzstan. Marvel at the breath-taking beauty of the Tien Shan Mountains, experience nomadic culture, and indulge in thrilling outdoor adventures. Hassle-free e-visa makes it even easier!

3️) Laos: Experience tranquillity in the serene land of Laos. Explore ancient temples in #LuangPrabang, cruise along the Mekong River, and bask in the untouched natural beauty of this enchanting destination. Visa on arrival for Indian travellers.

4️) Sri Lanka: Dive into the tropical paradise of Sri Lanka. From pristine beaches to lush tea plantations, this island nation offers a blend of natural wonders and rich cultural heritage. Visa-on-arrival is available for Indian passport holders.

5️) Cambodia: Unearth the wonders of Cambodia, from the awe-inspiring Angkor Wat to the vibrant streets of Phnom Penh. Immerse yourself in the country's fascinating history and savour the delightful local cuisine. Visa-on-arrival is accessible for Indians.

Embark on these unforgettable adventures without worrying about visa hassles or breaking the bank. 🌏✨

HEAVY RAIN WREAKS HAVOC IN HIMACHAL PRADESH

Over the last 3 days, the entire North India has been severely battered by heavy rainfall. The state worst affected by this deluge is Himachal Pradesh, which hasn't witnessed such "widespread heavy rains" in the past 50 years.

Social media is filled with terrifying images depicting the aftermath of landslides and flash floods triggered by incessant rain. Vehicles are seen floating like paper boats, muddy waters gushing into residential areas, and structures submerged on the banks of swollen rivers. Land cave-ins have also paralyzed normal life. It seems as if all major rivers, including Ravi, Beas, Satluj, Swan, and Chenab, have united to unleash their fury.

DAMAGE SO FAR

According to official records, more than 20 people have lost their lives so far. Over 17 bridges, and 1,300 roads (including major national highways, district, and link roads in the state), have been damaged. The state has incurred a loss of approximately Rs 3,000 crore in this monsoon season.

IS IT CLIMATE CHANGE INDUCED?

Absolutely. IPCC reports have made it abundantly clear, providing evidence of a warmer climate leading to these extreme weather events. This extreme weather serves as a sobering reminder of the urgent need to address climate change and its wide-ranging effects. Events like these have become more frequent and intense in recent years. According to climate scientists, they will continue to occur with increased severity and frequency as the atmosphere stores more moisture due to the rise in Earth's temperature caused by greenhouse gas emissions.

HOW CAN YOU CONTRIBUTE?

1) Avoid travelling to destinations grappling with over-tourism.
2) Reduce your carbon footprint by choosing sustainable activities such as hiking, cycling, or community travel.
3) Refrain from staying at properties that harm the environment.
4) Opt for travelling during shoulder seasons instead of peak seasons.
5) Remember, creating song-and-dance reels won't benefit a destination. Travelling responsibly will.

Do you know which is the birthplace of modern apples we eat?

Almaty in Kazakhstan.

The name “Almaty” is derived from the Kazakh word “alma,” meaning “apple.” Legend has it that the wild ancestor of the modern apple originated in this region. My local guide Valentina told me that once Almaty had apples as big as one kilogram. 

Besides apples, there are innumerable reasons to visit this hidden gem of central Asia:

1)	Visa on arrival: Almaty offers #VisaOnArrival for many nationalities, including India, making it convenient for travellers to visit without the need for extensive pre-trip arrangements.
2)	Direct flights: Almaty has direct flight connections with various international cities, making it easily accessible for travellers from around the world. My #AirAstana flight from Delhi to Almaty just took 3h15m.
3)	 Affordability: Almaty offers a budget-friendly travel experience with reasonably priced accommodations, dining options, and attractions, allowing you to make the most of your trip without breaking the bank.
4)	Offbeat destination: Almaty remains relatively undiscovered by mass tourism, providing a unique and authentic travel experience away from the crowds.
5)	Unique places to explore: Almaty is home to remarkable attractions such as the Shymbulak Ski Resort, Zenkov Cathedral church, Big Almaty Lake, Medeu Skating Rink, and Kok Tobe Hill. Each of these places offers distinct experiences, from outdoor adventures to cultural landmarks, ensuring a diverse and memorable visit.

Here are some postcards to inspire you to book your next holiday to Kazakhstan. And, if you do, book it through @embarqmotorworld. I genuinely loved how amazingly they plan their tours. @sujalpatwardhan & @medhajoseph are true rock stars!

Kazakhstan in Summers V/S Winters:

1)	Weather - In Almaty, the summers are warm, dry, and mostly clear, and the winters are freezing, quite chilly, snowy, and partly cloudy. 
2)	Activities – you can go hiking, cycling, horse riding, glamping, rafting and stargazing during summer, while in winter, you can skate at the world’s highest skating rink or ski at Shymbulak Ski Resort. You can also see Eagle Hunting in winter.
3)	Budget - Summer sees the most visitors; therefore, prices are a bit higher, whereas Winter is quiet, tourism-wise; therefore, exploring Kazakhstan in winter is quite economical.

📍Dal Lake near Mcleodganj is one such place where peace and beauty coexists. Moreover, it is one of the most revered lakes in Himachal. Every year in September a grand fair is organised at the banks of the Dal Lake, owing to the Shiva Temple here. This gala event is celebrated to mark the presence of Lord Shiva and is attended by a large number of people of the Gaddi Tribe.

While this place is worth visiting in any season, monsoon is a special time when the tall deodar trees and clouds play hide and seek with each other the whole day. Within a minute the whole lake becomes a veil of white smoke 💨 owing to moody rain clouds ☁️

Save this Reel for exploring 8 must-visit locations📍 in #McLeodGanj without breaking the bank! 🤩

1)	Barnet Village: A scenic 16km journey amidst oak, pine, and rhododendron trees. Entry - Free! 🚗🍃
2)	Dal Lake: A serene lake with Kashmir-like views, just 5km away from McLeodganj. Entry - Free! 🛶💦
3)	Naddi Point: Soak in the splendour of the Dauldhar range. Entry - Free! 🏔️😍
4)	St. John’s Baptist Church: One of the oldest churches in the region, built in 1852, with a unique charm. Entry - Free! ⛪✨
5)	Bhagsu Waterfall: A 30-foot cascade, only 3km from McLeodganj. Entry - Free! 🌊🍃
6)	Dharamshala Skyway: A 1.8km ropeway that takes you from Dharamshala to McLeodganj in just 10 minutes! Entry - ₹450 (one-way ticket), ₹675 (round trip) 🚡🏞️
7)	Dharamshala Stadium: A reliable and stunning stadium, among the tallest stadiums globally. Entry - ₹30! 🏟️🏏
8)	Himalayan Brew Tea Gardens: 150-year-old estate to relish the Kangra tea. Entry - Free ☕🫖

✨Who doesn’t know him? ✨

The most famous Bollywood kid - Taimur Ali Khan Pataudi - was named after the controversial 14th-century Turku-Mongol warrior – Amir Timur, who conquered most of Western and Central Asia and founded the Timurid Empire that comprised the modern-day countries of Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, large parts of Turkey and Syria, and the north-western portion of India (Delhi).

Even after 700 years of his death, he is still revered in Central Asia.

During my recent visit to #kazakhstan , I got an opportunity to see and understand why this last nomadic leader is still considered a national hero. 

I visited the ancient cities of #Sairam, #Ortar, #Shymkent and #Turkistan. Being on the #SilkRoute, these cities prospered and became cultural hubs during Timur’s reign.

Would you like to flip the history pages and visit Shymkent and Turkistan soon?

Visiting the Ancient City of Otrar

Ever wondered about those ghost towns that were once bustling hubs of trade and culture? Well, let me introduce you to #Otrar, a hidden gem nestled in the heart of #Turkistan, #Kazakhstan! 🕌

Picture yourself wandering through a city with a 2,000-year history, where echoes of ancient palaces, bathhouses, and mosques tell enchanting tales of its glorious past. Otrar, once a typical fortress of Central Asia, has surprises waiting to be unveiled. Recent excavations have revealed its advanced nature with monumental structures. Positioned at the crossroads of diverse landscapes and the intersection of caravan routes from the Great Silk Road, Otrar stood as a testament to its strategic importance.

Archaeological digs have traced its existence from the 1st century AD, enduring until the 15th century, despite facing invasions and tribal conflicts.

But here's the real kicker – even in those ancient times, the city had a hidden water carrier. How fascinating is that?

While the fortress still stands tall, it has witnessed the rise and fall of dynasties – Khwarazm Shahs, Mongol Khans, Timurid Amirs, Shaybanid Sultans – each leaving their indelible mark. Exploring Otrar felt like embarking on a journey through four distinct worlds, all within a single spot! From forgotten towns to awe-inspiring ceremonies, I glimpsed an entirely new facet of history right within the heart of Otrar.

Are you feeling the itch to turn the pages of history and experience Otrar for yourself?

Netherlands is famous worldwide for its tulips 💐🌷 . But did you know that the tulips didn’t originate in Netherlands? A fact unknown to many.

You’ll be surprised to know that the wild tulips 🌷 originated in the Central Asian region.

The first tulips came to the kingdom of the Netherlands over 400 years ago from #türkiye where they were brought from Central Asia. They originated in the mountainous regions and adjacent deserts of Kazakhstan and Central Asia more than 10 to 20 million years ago. From there, they spread to the west and the north.

Tulips were among the favorite motifs of Kazakh artisans to decorate gold and silver jewelry and clothing. These flowers were also depicted in the 10-11th century pottery found in Central Asia. They can be seen on the thin bricks of the Khoja Ahmed Yasawi mausoleum in the ancient city of Turkistan and the medieval ceramics of the ancient city of Otyrar.

And, the best time to see these amazing flowers 💐 to bloom is from March to June in Kazakhstan.

So, plan your trip to #shymkent Kazakhstan today.

social_posts.post_text:
Today, when I embarked on a remarkable journey through Hokkaido's Apoi Geological Park, I had no clue what I was going to see. 🌋🌿

What makes this place truly extraordinary is its UNESCO World Heritage status. 🌏🏛️ UNESCO recognized Apoi for its unparalleled geological significance. 📜🔍

Imagine, every rock, every formation, every landscape here is like a page in the Earth's history book, dating back millions of years. More than 13 million years ago, the park that we hiked through was actually a sea. It formed when two tectonic plates of Earth collided, creating a peridotite mountain (made of coarse plutonic rock), and a part of the mantle deep under the crust was thrust up onto the Earth's surface to form Mount Apoi. Swipe left and check out pic  #3 & last to understand more.🌄📖 Mt. Apoi is a living testament to the incredible forces that have shaped our planet over time unknown. 🌋💫

So, when you see me exploring this unique natural wonderland, I'm not just on a trip; I'm on a journey through time itself! 🕰️🏞️

Have you put Hokkaido on your travel map? If not, it's time to do it now!

Japan 🇯🇵 is a lot more than just shrines, sushi, sake and Shinkansen. 

If you love nature and adventure, head to Mt. Meakan, an incredible active volcano located in the Akan-Mashu National Park in Eastern Hokkaido of Japan. This hike is famous for its smouldering crater, pristine lakes, and twin volcanic peaks. 

The trail begins in a beautiful natural forest and eventually gives way to small shrubs and volcanic rocks. Ascent is 3.3 km and 4.4 km downhill taking approx 6-7 hours. Being an active volcano its impressive terrain and deep craters with fuming sulfuric steam vents and ponds, along with panoramic views from the summit, make climbing the mountain a particularly rewarding experience. 

Mt. Meakan (1,499 m) is the highest mountain in the Akan mountain range, and is a composite volcano consisting of 10 peaks created by various volcanic eruptions, starting approximately 50,000 years ago.

One of the best hiking experiences I had in Japan. 

When are you going to #visithokkaido in Japan?

Japan’s forgotten indigenous people, the Ainu, were the first inhabitants of Hokkaido, Japan’s northern island. Surprisingly, many travelers, including myself until a month ago, remain unfamiliar with their rich history and culture.

During my third visit to Japan, I discovered the compelling story of the Ainu. Their roots trace back thousands of years, but in the late 19th century, Hokkaido's annexation by Japan led to policies that nearly erased their history, traditions, language, and lifestyle, pushing Ainu culture to the brink of extinction. Today, with only around 26,000 Ainu people worldwide, efforts are being made to revive their heritage.

I had the privilege of delving into their traditions and lifestyle through various activities:

Nibutani Ainu Culture Museum: A captivating display of over 1000 exhibits, providing insights into all aspects of Ainu culture. I even tried my hand at carving an Ainu pattern into a wooden coaster.

Biratori’s Campground: Witnessed a prayer ceremony to Ainu spirit-deities, strolled through the mountains, visited an Ainu hunting shelter, and tried traditional hunting. The day concluded with a delightful barbecue dinner.

Kamuy Lumina, Lake Akan: An innovative retelling of a traditional Ainu song, taking me on a 1.2-kilometer walking path filled with light, sound, and images.

Akan Yukar “Lost Kamuy”: A rare opportunity to witness the fusion of Ainu ancient ceremonial dance, contemporary dance, 3-D digital imagery, and 7.1 surround sound in the largest Ainu village on Lake Akan.

These experiences have ignited my interest in Ainu culture, and I can’t wait to learn more on my next visit.

Have you heard about them before?

Is Akan-Mashu National Park and Kushiro worth visiting in Japan? 

YES. 100%!

Once you visit this unexplored gem in Eastern Hokkaido, you’ll wonder why you waited so long to explore its wonders. This place completely blew my mind and is home to three of Hokkaido’s six national parks, making it a must-visit at any time of the year. Here are my top reasons to love it:

1.	Lake Paradise - #AkanMashuNationalPark is famed for its large, clear caldera lakes—Lake Akan, Lake Mashu, and Lake Kussharo. Canoeing on Lake Kussharo was an incredible experience. And, the golden hour at Lake Akan is to die for. Also, Lake Akan is famous for its #marimo, a rare algae that forms into ball shapes.
2.	Hiking Live Volcanoes – The area is known for its visible volcanic activity in the form of hot springs, sleeping volcanoes, and bubbling mud fountains. I had an amazing time hiking Mt. Meakan and Atosa Nupuri.
3.	Learning about Ainu Culture - The Ainu, indigenous people of Japan, have their largest Ainu Kotan (village) located by Lake Akan in Akan-Mashu National Park.
4.	Kushiro Marshland - Kushiro Shitsugen National Park is the largest area of wetlands in Japan.
5.	Seafood – If you are a seafood lover then you’d go bonkers here. It’s a heaven for seafood lovers.

The list is endless. You must visit Kushiro to discover its raw, untouched beauty. 

Do swipe left to check all the pics.

A huge thanks to my amazing guide Masako Endo San and the entire team of JTB, Akan Adventures, Kushiro City, including Mayor Masayuki San, Kumagai San, Kazu San, Ernesto San, Yuto San, and the entire team that put together such an incredible trip.

Surprising facts about Japan!

Hey, folks!

Back with more mind-blowing quirks you’ll only find in Japan. 🇯🇵✨ Buckle up for this wild ride:

1.	Japanese fitting room etiquettes- Ever tried on clothes in Japan? It’s a whole new experience! Shoes off, face cover on (to keep that makeup off the outfit), take it off only after trying your fab ensemble. And remember, don’t leave anything behind—big no-no!💃👗
2.	Japanese public toilets? Absolute game-changer! Picture this: an automatic panel outside the toilet that updates you in real-time about which toilet is free. Plus, a nifty space to stash your valuables or keep an eye on your little one. Lights that turn on like magic, lids that dance open and close on their own, washlets for a spa-like clean, a music feature to drown out any awkward sounds, and flushing that’s completely hands-free—basically, you just show up, and the toilet does the rest! 🚽✨ 
3.	Say sayonara to lugging heavy bags! 🛄 I wanted to see as much Japan as possible but didn’t want to carry my heavy luggage around. So, I sent my 23kg monster luggage to my final stop with a slick delivery system for just 2080 yen. All I had to do was ask the hotel about the service and they did everything for me. Easy peasy! 🛄💼 🏨✨
4.	Yukata vibes! Most Hotels in Japan offer these cool, casual kimonos called Yukata made of cotton or synthetic fabric. Perfect for lounging in style! 🎎💫
5.	Japanese taxis are on another planet! Spotlessly clean and reliable. Doors open and close themselves, language translation on board, and various payment options. It’s like a ride to the future! 🚖🌐✨

Tokyo must-see!🚀

Ready for a mind-blowing experience in Tokyo? Check out @teamlab.planets! 🚀

Going to museums and art galleries will never be the same after you’ve visited the @teamlab.planets museum in Tokyo. 

It is not your typical art museum but an immersive paradise where you’re not just an observer, but part of the art. The exhibits here blend art, science, and nature in ways that change in response to your touch and movement, creating a unique experience every time you move an inch.

Let’s dive into the magic: There are 4 large-scale exhibits & 2 gardens

1.	The Infinite Crystal Universe: 300,000 LED lights create a shimmering wonderland. Walk through hanging crystals that change colours with every step.
2.	Drawing on the Water Surface: A room with a massive pool, clear water, and lively koi fish. Your moves create ripples, turning the space into a living canvas.
3.	Giant Balls Room: Walk through giant colour-shifting balls. Touch them, and watch the space around you transform with your every move.
4.	Floating in the Falling Universe of Flowers: Delicate petals fall from the ceiling, creating a mesmerizing dance of colours.

Two Gardens:
1.	Floating Flower Garden: Walk through a room filled with thousands of real flowers reflecting in mirrors above you.
2.	Moss Garden of Resonating Microcosm: Touch egg-shaped objects that change colour and sound in the moss garden.

There are many additional small exhibits too. I couldn’t resist strolling through the Waterfall of Light Particles and the Soft Black Hole—velvety darkness where moving forward felt like a delightful fall.

In Tokyo? This modern art museum is a must-do! 🌌🖼️

Do you know which city is called the cultural capital of Japan?

KYOTO

Founded in 794, Kyoto was Japan's capital for over 1,000 years. Though Tokyo took over as the seat of governmental power in 1868, Kyoto remains the cultural heart of Japan. It’s the birthplace of many traditional arts, from kabuki theatre to the refined #kaiseki cuisine—passed down by artisans through generations.

If you're planning a trip to Japan, I highly urge you to keep Kyoto on your itinerary. Here are the must-visit places and activities:

1.	Kinkakuji Temple (金閣寺, Golden Pavilion) - The top two floors are covered in gold leaf.
2.	Tenryuji (天龍寺, Tenryūji) - The most important temple in Kyoto's Arashiyama district, a UNESCO world heritage site.
3.	Arashiyama Bamboo Grove - An endless forest of swaying bamboo, open 24/7 and admission is free.
4.	Togetsu Bridge - A 155-meter bridge across the Katsura River.
5.	Ryoanji - Japan's most famous rock garden.
6.	Kiyomizu-dera Temple - A UNESCO world heritage site known for its large wooden terrace.
7.	Kyoto Samurai Museum - Japan's only museum dedicated to the history of samurais and ninjas.
8.	Wear a Kimono and attend a traditional Tea Ceremony in the historic Gion district.
9.	Enjoy the majestic scenery of Arashiyama Kyoto on a unique guided rickshaw tour.
10.	Take a Hozukawa river boat ride from Kameoka to Arashiyama with a rich history dating back more than 400 years.
11.	Shop and eat in the Nishiki Market (錦市場, Nishiki Ichiba) - A narrow, five-block-long shopping street lined with more than one hundred shops and restaurants.

Kyoto, a top spot in Japan, paints a vivid picture of tradition and beauty. When you imagine Japan, two iconic scenes come to mind:

1.	Vermilion torii gates of Fushimi Inari Shrine (伏見稲荷大社, Fushimi Inari Taisha) – The pinnacle shrine in Kyoto, dedicated to Inari, the Shinto god of rice. Famous for its thousands of vermilion torii gates, leading into the sacred forest of Mount Inari. A spiritual journey like no other at 233 meters high.

2.	Nara, Japan’s deer-loving ancient capital - Nestled next to Kyoto and Osaka, Nara was Japan’s first permanent capital. Here, 1400 sacred deer roam narrow streets. Once revered as messengers of the gods, they now bow to visitors, charming their way into treats. Beyond the deer, Nara boasts three World Heritage sites. A living museum with 1,300 years of art and architecture, enriched by ideas and technology from Europe, China, and Korea via the Silk Road.

How to experience Osaka on a budget in just 2 days! 🏰🌆

Osaka isn't just about sights—it's a fusion of local food culture, vibrant nightlife, edgy architecture, endless shopping, year-round festivities, and traditional arts dating back centuries.

Due to limited time and health constraints, I couldn't explore Osaka as much as I wanted, but here's a curated 2-day itinerary for you:

1.	Osaka Castle and its scenic park – climb to the observation deck for panoramic city views.
2.	Sakishima Cosmo Tower Observatory or Umeda Sky Building for breathtaking cityscapes.
3.	Osaka Bay Area for the Aquarium and Tempozan Ferris Wheel.
4.	Twilight Cruise on Cruise Ship Santa Maria for a stunning Osaka Bay sunset.
5.	Indulge in unique Osaka eats at Kuromon Market.
6.	Explore Dotombori and Shinsaibashi, home to the iconic Ebisu-bashi Bridge.
7.	Shinsekai ("New World") – visit Tsutenkaku Tower at the district's center.
8.	Must-try Osaka foods: Takoyaki, Okonomiyaki, Karaage, Kitsune Udon, Kushikatsu, Teppanyaki, and more.
9.	For Japanese whisky lovers, Suntory Yamazaki Distillery tour (resumes from Nov 1, 2023).
10.	Thrill-seekers, don't miss Universal Studios Osaka.

Is Hiroshima worth visiting in Japan? 

Absolutely.

A trip to Japan isn't truly complete without experiencing the profound history of Hiroshima. If you're keen to delve into Japan's past, Hiroshima is an absolute must-visit.

For many, Hiroshima has been synonymous with the haunting images of August 6, 1945—the day it became the target of the world's first atomic-bomb attack at the end of World War II. Hiroshima's Peace Memorial Park stands as a poignant reminder, drawing over a million visitors annually with its powerful message of peace.

The park, adorned with memorials and tranquil spaces, centers around the Pond of Peace—a tree-lined reflection space leading to the cenotaph holding the names of over 220,000 known victims. The Flame of Peace, flickering until all nuclear weapons are destroyed, adds another layer of significance.

Adjacent to the park, the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum narrates the harsh reality of the atomic bombing through preserved artifacts. It offers a human perspective on the devastation and the city's selection as a target.

Across the river stands the stark reminder of WWII's destruction—the Atomic Bomb Dome. Preserved since 1915, it now serves as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, a haunting symbol of resilience.

Visiting these places is emotionally impactful, but Hiroshima isn't just a city weighed down by its past. It's a vibrant, cosmopolitan community that has risen from the ashes. Spending a couple of nights here unveils the city at its vibrant best.

So, when's your trip to Hiroshima?

Hiroshima, a bustling city with a tragic past. 

On August 6, 1945, the first atomic bomb wreaked unimaginable havoc within a 2km radius, reshaping the city. Yet, Hiroshima stands today as an enduring testament to resilience, beckoning with diverse attractions.

Are you visiting Hiroshima? make sure you visit these places that I am visiting at the moment.

1.	Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park 🌸 A sanctuary of hope, the park is a poignant reminder of war’s horrors. There are several monuments here, most notable being the cenotaph, holding the names of over 220,000 known victims.

Next to the Peace Park stands the UNESCO World Heritage site - A-BOMB dome, one of the very few bomb sites that survived the nuclear blast. 

2.	Hiroshima Castle 🏰 
Standing in the heart of the city, this castle, was built on a plain not mountaintop in 1589. Despite being destroyed in 1945 during the nuclear attack, it was meticulously rebuilt using the original methods and materials. 

3.	Shukkeien Garden 🍃 Adjacent to Hiroshima Castle, Shukkeien Garden is a masterpiece of miniature landscapes — a garden mirroring valleys, mountains, and forests, as if plucked from a Murakami novel.

4.	Miyajima Island ⛩️ A sacred island, Just a short boat ride away from Hiroshima, is a sacred gem. Itsukushima Shrine, seemingly floating during high tide, and the iconic Giant Tori Gate make it a must-visit. Considered one of Japan’s best three views.

5.	Okonomiyaki 🥢 No journey is complete without savouring Hiroshima’s soul food—Okonomiyaki. A lovechild of pancake and pizza, cooked to perfection on a sizzling hot plate.

So, these are your must-visit places in Hiroshima. Hope it helps in planning your trip to Japan.

Singapore Zoo is One of the top three zoos in the world and even this animal lover, who usually shies away from zoos, was smitten. Here’s why Singapore Zoo deserves a spot on your island nation itinerary:

1.	🏞️ Large Natural Enclosures: It’s not a zoo; it’s an open haven! Most animals roam freely in expansive, natural enclosures with moats and minimal fencing. 

2.	🌍 Diverse Habitats: With over 2,800 animals from 300 species across 12 zones, from Australasia to Wild Africa, Singapore Zoo replicates diverse animal habitats worldwide.

3.	🦧 Free-Ranging Orangutans: Witness the world’s first free-ranging orangutan habitat, which mirrors their natural habitat. Here you can meet both Bornean and Sumatran orangutans, including the iconic Ah Meng, a Sumatran orangutan who became a tourism icon.

4.	🌅 Jungle Breakfast in the Wild: Experience a first-of-its-kind Jungle Breakfast With Wildlife, where you can enjoy the day’s first meal in the company of charming orangutans.

5.	🦓 Wildlife Encounters: Go behind the scenes, get up close with the animals, and discover their unique traits.

6.	🗣️ Keeper Talks: Hear fascinating stories from the zookeepers, and even feed the animals yourself for an interactive experience.

Still, debating? Don’t wait — just book it. I assure you an unparalleled zoo experience awaits at Singapore Zoo! 🌟🦓

Diving into Hokkaido's Onsen Wonderland! 🌊 

Did you know Hokkaido, Japan's northern gem, is a hot spring haven with 251 Onsen areas? From the moment you step off the plane at Chitose Airport to the serene landscapes, Hokkaido is sprinkled with therapeutic hot springs waiting to be discovered.

💧 Each Onsen, be it #Oyunuma, #Jozankei, #Shikotuko, #Toyako, #Noboribetsu, or #Asarigawa, is a unique experience with distinct healing properties. Fun fact: it would take 251 days to explore them all! But what makes Hokkaido's Onsen culture truly special?

🔥 Enter the Onsen masters and Onsen sommeliers-the unsung heroes of this therapeutic tradition. With only 5 Onsen masters in all of Japan and a staggering 26,000 Onsen sommeliers, they're the guides to Onsen etiquette and maximizing the benefits of these natural wonders.

📚 These Onsen aficionados teach us the art of relaxation, sharing the secrets of Onsen manners and the science behind the benefits. Why does Japan have such a profound Onsen culture? Two words: geothermal wonders. Japan's geothermal onsens are a gift from nature, offering unparalleled tranquillity and healing properties.

🌡️ Additionally, Japanese people, have a slightly lower average body temperature of around 36°C, compared to the 37°C for the rest of the world. This unique trait adds to the harmony of soaking in Hokkaido's geothermal onsens. 🌡️✨.

So, let's soak in the culture, follow the Onsen rules, and let the Onsen masters and sommeliers guide us to a world of relaxation. 🧖‍♀️🧖‍♂️✨ 

Discover more about Hokkaido's wonders in my latest blog post, "10 REASONS TO VISIT HOKKAIDO: FROM AINU CULTURE TO WINTER WONDERS, YOUR ULTIMATE GUIDE." Link in bio! 🌟

Have you heard about Kok-Boru?

Kok-Boru is one of Kyrgyzstan's most popular national horse games, holding immense cultural significance as horses remain integral to Kyrgyz culture. Played for centuries, this traditional Kyrgyz game involves two teams on horseback competing to score as many 'ulaks' (score points) by carrying a deceased goat or sheep carcass, known as "buzkashi," into their opponents' goal. The game is intense and physically demanding, requiring riders to maneuver their horses to obstruct and challenge opponents, vying for possession of the carcass.

Beyond being a sport, Kok-Boru is a cultural tradition deeply woven into Kyrgyz life. Celebrating the country's nomadic heritage and strong equestrian culture, the game is a fixture at special events and festivals. It even plays a role in Kyrgyz marriage rituals, where a suitor must showcase his horsemanship to win a girl's hand, outriding and kissing her. In competitive scenarios, multiple suitors may contend on horseback, with the last man in the saddle emerging victorious.

Would you like to travel to Kyrgyzstan to witness #kokboru?

🎄✨ Attended my first-ever Journey to Christmas festival in Moscow and it was an absolute dream come true! 🌟 This once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to experience the magic of the holiday season in the heart of Europe has left me in awe. 🎅🏻✨

For the past 10 years, “Journey to Christmas” has been the largest and most visited festival in Europe, and this year, it’s celebrating its 10th anniversary! With 36 festival grounds spread throughout the city, Moscow has truly transformed into a Christmas wonderland. 🎉🎁

From enchanting illuminations to stunning art installations, ice shows, and theatrical performances, every corner of the festival is filled with the spirit of Christmas. 🎭⛸️ And let’s not forget about the mouthwatering festive treats and unique gifts that await you at every turn. 🍭🎁

One of my favorite highlights was the “Moscow Tea Party” project, where I had the chance to learn about the capital’s tea-drinking traditions and savor a cup of hot tea from an authentic old samovar. ☕️✨

But that’s not all! The festival also offers a wide range of sports and gastronomic events. With over 4,000 creative and culinary master classes, more than 10,000 sweet gifts, and over 1,500 performances, there’s something for everyone to enjoy. 🎉🍽️

And the cherry on top? More than 100 ice shows featuring the best figure skaters of Russia, bringing beloved fairy tales like “Nutcracker,” “Snow White,” “Cinderella,” “Princess Frog,” and “Buratino” to life on the ice. ⛸️❄️

If you’re looking for an unforgettable holiday experience, mark your calendars and join me at the “Journey to Christmas” festival in Moscow. Trust me, you won’t want to miss out on this magical celebration! 🎄✨ 

#JourneyToChristmas #MoscowSeasons #festivemagic #travelseewrite #happynewyear2024 #russia #visitrussia #christmasdecorations

Yahan Christmas na dekha toh kuch nahi dekha.

Come, let me take you on a journey to Christmas like no other.

Since 2013, Moscow hosts a grand New Year and Christmas festival called ‘Journey to Christmas,’ from December 15 to January 8.

In the past 10 years, it has become the biggest and most visited festival in Europe. The entire city transforms into a fairy-tale town, unlike most European cities, with vibrant lights, colorful decorations, art objects, and numerous surprises.

This year, the Moscow Seasons organized the festival in 36 grounds, featuring over 4,000 masterclasses, 10,000 sweet gifts, 1,500 performances, and 100+ ice shows. Olympic champions performed traditional Russian classics on 22 skating rinks. Special chalets offered unique Christmas food and drinks.

My favorite was the Moscow Tea Party, where I learned about Moscow’s old tea-drinking traditions, feeling like I stepped into the Tsar era of the 19th century.

Here, instead of Santa Claus, we have Father Frost and his granddaughter Snow Maiden.

‘Journey to Christmas’ was a magical experience for me, a perfect blend of traditions and celebrations. I hope you get to witness Moscow’s Christmas magic next year!

social_posts.post_text:
Flashback to a December 2018 hike near Sojha-Jalori pass in Himachal Pradesh, where snow-covered landscapes painted a picturesque scene. Fast forward to today, and the absence of snowfall is evident. Himachal is experiencing a dry January after a hiatus of 17 years, with the first eight days recording no rainfall. This shift in weather patterns poses challenges for farmers in the low-lying hills and plains, grappling with the dual impact of fog and drought.

The repercussions are significant, especially for crops like apples, peas, wheat, and garlic. This is not an isolated anomaly; we witnessed Himachal and Uttarakhand battling unprecedented flash floods caused by heavy rains in 2023. It’s a wake-up call to acknowledge the real and tangible effects of climate change.

However, it’s not all doom and gloom. Climate change is evident, but the solution isn’t about spreading fear. Instead, let’s make a positive impact by reconsidering our travel choices. Rather than exerting undue pressure on popular destinations, why not explore the charm of offbeat places? Swap Manali for the serenity of Shaangarh, choose Thanedar over Shimla, opt for Pauri instead of Pahalgam, revel in the beauty of Munsiyari over Mussorie, and experience the pristine Guru Dongmar over the bustling Gulmarg.

Embracing sustainable travel practices can make a significant impact. By choosing lesser-known destinations and traveling in the shoulder season, we not only reduce the strain on heavily visited areas but also discover hidden gems that contribute to a more resilient and sustainable tourism ecosystem.

Join the movement towards sustainable travel for a greener and more resilient tomorrow! 🌍❄️ 

#TravelSeeWrite #DekhoApnaDesh #OffbeatTravel #ClimateChangeAwareness #ExploreResponsibly #SustainableTravel #changeisinourhands #climatechange #himachaltourism

Can Lakshadweep handle its growing popularity? 🏝️✨ 

As public interest peaks in this tiny paradise, the challenge of maintaining its magic escalates – with over-tourism looming as the most significant risk.

The first step towards overcoming this challenge is understanding Lakshadweep’s ‘Carrying Capacity.’ 

But what exactly is ‘Carrying Capacity’? 🤔🌍 

It’s the delicate balance between exploration and preservation, akin to a lift’s weight limit. Essentially, it defines the maximum load a destination can bear without harming its environment, culture, and experience quality. 🌊💚

This capacity becomes a tool to formulate actionable steps for protecting fragile environments like Lakshadweep:

1.	Limit visitors,
2.	Educate tourists,
3.	Involve local communities,
4.	Build regenerative infrastructure.

It’s that simple! Your role in this story? Be a responsible traveler, respect the island, and spread the word.

Let’s create an unbroken connection in preserving Lakshadweep’s unique charm! 🙌🏽✈️
